org.usfirst.frc.team2077.video.interfaces

Interface SourceProjection

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractProjection, Birdseye, CubeMap3x2, Equidistant, Equirectangular, Equisolid, InverseTangentProjection, Orthographic, Perspective, SineProjection, Stereographic, TangentProjection

    public interface SourceProjection
    Back projection and coordinate transform math for video input. The purpose of the source projection is to normalize input to common world space spherical coordinates regardless of camera lens geometry. This permits merging of video data from multiple cameras (even with differing lens types) and independent specification of viewing projections.

    While the interface defines several methods, its core is sourceProjection(double, double), which describes the pure lens function by mapping from spherical world coordinates to normalized cartesian projection space. Other functions may typically be handled in a common base class.

    Source projections are created by VideoSources and are required to have a constructor taking parameters (String name, VideoSource videoSource), where name is its configuration property prefix and videoSource is the calling VideoSource.

    Â© 2018

    Author:
    FRC Team 2077, R. A. Buchanan

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      double[] sourceProjection(double azimuth, double polar)
      Maps source-relative spherical view vector to normalized source projection coordinates.
      double[] transformCartesianToPixel(double x, double y)
      Maps a point in normalized source projection coordinates to source image space.
      double[] transformGlobalWorldToSource(double azimuth, double polar)
      Maps global spherical view vector to source-relative spherical coordinates.
      double[] transformNominalWorldToSource(double azimuth, double polar)
      Maps nominal source-relative spherical view vector to source-relative spherical coordinates.

    • Method Detail

      • transformGlobalWorldToSource

        double[] transformGlobalWorldToSource(double azimuth,
                                      double polar)
        Maps global spherical view vector to source-relative spherical coordinates.
        Parameters:
        azimuth - World-relative spherical azimuth angle in radians clockwise from upward.
        polar - World-relative spherical polar angle in radians outward from view axis.
        Returns:
        {
        azimuth (Image-relative spherical azimuth angle in radians clockwise from upward),
        polar (Image-relative spherical normal angle in radians outward from view axis)
        }.

      • transformNominalWorldToSource

        double[] transformNominalWorldToSource(double azimuth,
                                       double polar)
        Maps nominal source-relative spherical view vector to source-relative spherical coordinates.
        Parameters:
        azimuth - Nominal source-relative spherical azimuth angle in radians clockwise from upward.
        polar - Nominal source spherical polar angle in radians outward from view axis.
        Returns:
        {
        azimuth (Image-relative spherical azimuth angle in radians clockwise from upward),
        polar (Image-relative spherical normal angle in radians outward from view axis)
        }.

      • sourceProjection

        double[] sourceProjection(double azimuth,
                          double polar)
        Maps source-relative spherical view vector to normalized source projection coordinates.
        Parameters:
        azimuth - Viewer-relative spherical azimuth angle in radians clockwise from upward.
        polar - Viewer-relative spherical polar angle in radians outward from view axis.
        Returns:
        {
        x (Horizontal projection space coordinate in range -1 to 1),
        y (Vertical projection space coordinate on same scale).
        }.

      • transformCartesianToPixel

        double[] transformCartesianToPixel(double x,
                                   double y)
        Maps a point in normalized source projection coordinates to source image space.
        Parameters:
        x - Horizontal projection space coordinate in range -1 to 1.
        y - Vertical projection space coordinate on same scale.
        Returns:
        {
        pixelX, (Horizontal image coordinate in range 0 to width from left).
        pixelY (Vertical image coordinate in range 0 to width from top).
        }
